stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the session building and testing a new “pentapus” Yoshi boss for Course 15. Work focuses on tentacle hit-detection using spline collision, animation timing, black-hole spawn points, warning lights, and overall fight flow. He also reviews total boss count, side-level plans, critiques fan PC ports, and shows a new low-cost reflection shader developed with contributor Akumoid.

development_findings.summary: Course 15’s boss is a corrupted Yoshi ‘pentapus.’  Five tentacles emerge from blue-hole portals; each tentacle carries a tumor (ward) that the player must destroy, after which Yoshi’s head drops so Mario can punch additional tumors on the nose.  Three cycles finish the fight.
development_findings.quote: You jump on his tentacle, you destroy the ward and then Yoshi gets weak … you punch the ward and that's dealing damage to him.

development_findings.summary: Tentacle paths are spline-based; Kaze writes code to record tentacle positions, render wards, and generate matching spline hitboxes for precise collision.
development_findings.quote: We need to write out the position of the tentacle, render the ward, and then use spline hitboxes to figure out where the tentacle hitboxes are.

development_findings.summary: Black-hole portals spawn exactly 400 units above ground; Kaze adds animated scale-up, a visible blue light cone, and camera shake to telegraph attacks while tuning speed and size for fairness.
Akumoid and Kaze produced a cheap N64-compliant reflection shader for metallic buildings and are now applying it to a rocket model; the effect costs almost no performance.
development_findings.quote: You'd think this is expensive, but this is literally free.

development_findings.summary: Total main-course bosses set to nine (in 15 courses); side-level plan expanded from six to about nine optional stages.
Kaze intends to hide encrypted Easter-egg messages in the boss text boxes and has already devised two encryption methods, seeking a few more.
development_findings.quote: I had the craziest idea for Easter eggs … he’s going to leave cryptic messages for you … I already have two encryption techniques thought of.

development_findings.summary: Kaze considers using YSK static recompilation to ship native builds (Android, etc.) instead of relying on emulators.
development_findings.quote: I might legitimately just use YSK static recompilation to properly import the game to like everything at once.

context_findings.summary: Kaze avoids political statements to preserve broad goodwill (‘halo effect’) and openly acknowledges it as a strategy.
context_findings.quote: If no one knows what my political beliefs are then people are more likely to assume my political beliefs overlap with theirs and they will like me for it.

context_findings.summary: He becomes visibly annoyed at repeated small-talk questions (‘How are you?’) during streams, seeing them as forced politeness.
context_findings.quote: How are you doing? That's like my least favorite question … it’s people being polite, but it's also pissing me off.

context_findings.summary: He maintains a policy that fans may port his hacks without help, but he becomes irritated when they request support for poorly executed ports.
context_findings.quote: If you can do it on yourself without my help you can do with my hacks whatever you want, but as soon as you start asking me for help I'm gonna be annoyed.

biobak.summary: Provided initial concept art for the pentapus; will remake Kaze’s placeholder model into final high-quality graphics.

badub.summary: Composes music for the project; Kaze jokes about Badub’s ‘royalty’ status after chat recognizes his tracks on SoundCloud.

zeina.summary: Currently building the outside area of Course 13; progress described as on-going for ‘a long time now.’

key_stories.title: Forging the Pentapus
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a mutated Yoshi boss with spline-based tentacles, tumors, and blue-hole portals, iterating on collision, lighting, and animation to balance spectacle and fairness.
key_stories.challenge: Create a memorable final-course boss that feels fresh on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Draft placeholder model, code spline logic, add warning lights, scale timings, and test hit detection while planning cryptic Easter-egg dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: Playable first pass of the fight exists; art to be replaced by Biobak and attack variety still to be added.
key_stories.key_quote: Right now he's just programmed to always go into his weak state after like everything, but the tentacles are going to come out of black holes so it will look like pull-up.

key_stories.title: Cheap Reflection Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Community member Akumoid works with Kaze to create a near-free reflection shader for metallic surfaces.
key_stories.challenge: Add modern-looking reflections without exceeding N64 performance limits.
key_stories.process: Exchange DM experiments on N64 shader tricks, separate reflection mask from base texture, implement and test on space-station building.
key_stories.outcome: Live demo shows convincing reflections; shader slated for the rocket model next.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at the building now. You see the reflections on it? I'm very happy with this.

key_stories.title: Evaluating Fan PC Ports
key_stories.summary: Chat shows Kaze several attempts to port earlier hacks to the SM64 PC port and Co-op Deluxe.
key_stories.challenge: Community desire for native ports versus quality control.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviews footage, points out missing backgrounds, broken physics, and unimplemented mechanics, explaining why proper ports are difficult.
key_stories.outcome: Sets expectation that accurate RTYI porting will be nearly impossible without source, reiterates policy of non-involvement.
key_stories.key_quote: I can clearly see that some parts of this are pretty rough … that's like barely even a port; you just rip the model and put the stars in there.
